author: LEVI PULKKINEN, SEATTLEPI.COM STAFF
title: Could Washington succeed by seceding?
text:
Photo: Marian Lockhart, Courtesy Boeing Image 4 of 21 Unproductive polarization: Washington has its share of bright blue (Seattle) and blazing red (looking at you, Davenport), but the state has a history of moderation that’s hard to imagine returning with today’s national politics. less Unproductive polarization: Washington has its share of bright blue (Seattle) and blazing red (looking at you, Davenport), but the state has a history of moderation that’s hard to imagine returning with ... more Photo: GENNA MARTIN, SEATTLEPI.COM Image 5 of 21 The structural problem : As Washington grows, it gets weaker, politically speaking. The constructions of the Electoral College and U.S. Senate both favor smaller, shrinking states. Both institutions shape the judiciary, too, which further disenfranchises the state’s voters. less The structural problem : As Washington grows, it gets weaker, politically speaking. The constructions of the Electoral College and U.S. Senate both favor smaller, shrinking states. Both institutions shape the ... more Photo: J. Scott Applewhite, AP Image 6 of 21 Not our wall: Our industries, from the apple orchards to Amazon, rely on a steady flow of immigrants. The policy that is good for Washington is apparently unpalatable for much of the country. Not our wall: Our industries, from the apple orchards to Amazon, rely on a steady flow of immigrants. The policy that is good for Washington is apparently unpalatable for much of the country. Photo: GRANT HINDSLEY, SEATTLEPI.COM Image 7 of 21 New arrivals, new money: About 13 percent of state residents were born in another country – approximately the national average. In Seattle, 22 percent of residents aren’t native-born Americans. Most of the increasingly affluent Eastside cities boast even higher percentages of foreign-born residents. less New arrivals, new money: About 13 percent of state residents were born in another country – approximately the national average. In Seattle, 22 percent of residents aren’t native-born Americans. Most of the ... more Photo: JOSHUA TRUJILLO, SEATTLEPI.COM Image 8 of 21 Refugees : The Seattle area has been shaped by refugees. They fled famine in Norway, Italy and Ireland, oppression and lack of opportunity in the American South, and, more recently, war and upheaval in Vietnam, the former USSR and East Africa. Ask the tourists buying flowers at Pike Place Market if the community isn’t more vibrant for it. less Refugees : The Seattle area has been shaped by refugees. They fled famine in Norway, Italy and Ireland, oppression and lack of opportunity in the American South, and, more recently, war and upheaval in Vietnam, ... more Photo: GRANT HINDSLEY, SEATTLEPI.COM Image 9 of 21 Trade: Even before William Boeing’s first seaplane soared, Washington’s economy was global. Protectionism threatens the state’s longtime rural moneymakers – agriculture, fisheries and timber – as well as the newer urban global players like Microsoft and Amazon. less Trade: Even before William Boeing’s first seaplane soared, Washington’s economy was global. Protectionism threatens the state’s longtime rural moneymakers – agriculture, fisheries and timber – as well ... more Photo: Genna Martin Image 10 of 21 Marijuana: Anyone who claims to know what the Trump administration intends for marijuana legalization is lying. A federal crackdown could derail the fledgling marijuana industry in Washington state, launched with the overwhelming support of state voters. Doing so would be trouble for Olympia, where lawmakers are depending on pot taxes to prop up the state budget. less Marijuana: Anyone who claims to know what the Trump administration intends for marijuana legalization is lying. A federal crackdown could derail the fledgling marijuana industry in Washington state, launched ... more Photo: GENNA MARTIN, SEATTLEPI.COM Image 11 of 21 Tribal rights: Native Americans in this Washington have been winning their fight for a seat at the table. The Trump administration has shown no interest in protecting the rights of Indian people and appears poised to bully them on the indigenous-rights issue of the day – the Dakota Access pipeline. less Tribal rights: Native Americans in this Washington have been winning their fight for a seat at the table. The Trump administration has shown no interest in protecting the rights of Indian people and appears ... more Photo: Associated Press Image 12 of 21 Public lands: Washingtonians know well the conflicts that pop up when deciding how to use or preserve public land. Are they really best dealt with from D.C., particularly when an anti-public-land ideology seems to be driving the discussion? less Public lands: Washingtonians know well the conflicts that pop up when deciding how to use or preserve public land. Are they really best dealt with from D.C., particularly when an anti-public-land ideology seems ... more Photo: Paul Joseph Brown, Seattle Post-Intelligencer Image 13 of 21 Our sound and rivers: For decades now, Washingtonians of all political stripes have fought to fix the environmental disasters of generations past. That work could be undone from the other Washington, as rules meant to restrain polluters fall away. less Our sound and rivers: For decades now, Washingtonians of all political stripes have fought to fix the environmental disasters of generations past. That work could be undone from the other Washington, as rules ... more Image 14 of 21 Climate change: Washington may be well situated to face the hotter, drier future. Other states, including many that are still gleefully playing in the carbon economy, are not. In any case, most of our leaders recognize the moral imperative to act. Those calling the shots in D.C. do not. less Climate change: Washington may be well situated to face the hotter, drier future. Other states, including many that are still gleefully playing in the carbon economy, are not. In any case, most of our leaders ... more Photo: JOSHUA TRUJILLO, SEATTLEPI.COM Image 15 of 21 Old oil: States to our east (and provinces to our north) would happily ship coal and oil through Washington to factories in China. It may benefit workers in the oil fields and coal mines, and it is certainly good for their employers. But what does Washington get for all those coal cars and oil tankers with their spill risks? less Old oil: States to our east (and provinces to our north) would happily ship coal and oil through Washington to factories in China. It may benefit workers in the oil fields and coal mines, and it is certainly ... more Photo: GRANT HINDSLEY, SEATTLEPI.COM Image 16 of 21 Big bust: It’s hardly gospel, but some economists warn that a collapse in the oil and coal economy is coming. Secession wouldn’t stop that, but Washington could at least dodge some of the burdens of an industry that has provided the state with few benefits. less Big bust: It’s hardly gospel, but some economists warn that a collapse in the oil and coal economy is coming. Secession wouldn’t stop that, but Washington could at least dodge some of the burdens of an ... more Photo: Matthew Brown, AP Image 17 of 21 Oregon: They’d want a piece of the secession action, if only to keep the angry Southwestern ranchers off their wildlife preserves. Oregon: They’d want a piece of the secession action, if only to keep the angry Southwestern ranchers off their wildlife preserves. Photo: Chris Pietsch, Associated Press Image 18 of 21 The other big C: Do we really want to have to follow California’s lead if #CalExit goes anywhere? That would be an embarrassing start to a new nation. And they’d probably put the bear on the flag. The other big C: Do we really want to have to follow California’s lead if #CalExit goes anywhere? That would be an embarrassing start to a new nation. And they’d probably put the bear on the flag. Photo: Gabrielle Lurie, The Chronicle Image 19 of 21 Canada: America’s hat could be Washington’s best friend after the Trump administration’s "America First" policies inevitably strain relations between the two countries. Canada: America’s hat could be Washington’s best friend after the Trump administration’s "America First" policies inevitably strain relations between the two countries. Photo: GRANT HINDSLEY, SEATTLEPI.COM Image 20 of 21 Beer supremacy: President Trump may be a teetotaler, but America loves the suds. And, as it happens, Washington produces 75 percent of America’s hops. Were Oregon to break alongside the Evergreen State, we’d hold 88 percent of the nation’s hop harvest. Delicious beer would require our help. less Beer supremacy: President Trump may be a teetotaler, but America loves the suds. And, as it happens, Washington produces 75 percent of America’s hops. Were Oregon to break alongside the Evergreen State, ... more Photo: JOSHUA TRUJILLO, SEATTLEPI.COM Could Washington succeed by seceding? 1 / 21 Back to Gallery 
It’s one of the strange things out here in the West. Folks back east don’t really get it. 
We’re pretty comfy with secession. 
Remember Sarah Palin’s husband, Todd. 
It made a minor rumble after Palin was tapped to join John McCain on the 2008 GOP presidential ticket. It turned out Todd -- the snowmobile-racing, oilfield-working fisherman -- was also Todd the former Alaska Independence Party member. Related Stories
